subsection.title: Properties of inner products
subsection.p: Here we list algebraic properties of inner products, including those prescribed by the inner product axioms.

proposition.title: Algebra rules of real inner products

statement.p:
Suppose \inprod{\blank}{\blank} is a real inner product. Then the following are true for all vectors \uvec{u}, \uvec{v}, and \uvec{w} in the associated inner product space, and all scalars k.
\uvecinprod{v}{u} = \uvecinprod{u}{v}.
\inprod{\uvec{u}}{\uvec{v} + \uvec{w}} = \uvecinprod{u}{v} + \uvecinprod{u}{w}.
\inprod{\uvec{u}}{\uvec{v} - \uvec{w}} = \uvecinprod{u}{v} - \uvecinprod{u}{w}.
\inprod{\uvec{u} + \uvec{v}}{\uvec{w}} = \uvecinprod{u}{w} + \uvecinprod{v}{w}.
\inprod{\uvec{u} - \uvec{v}}{\uvec{w}} = \uvecinprod{u}{w} - \uvecinprod{v}{w}.
\inprod{k \uvec{u}}{\uvec{v}} = k \uvecinprod{u}{v}.
\inprod{\uvec{u}}{k \uvec{v}} = k \uvecinprod{u}{v}.
\uvecinprod{v}{v} = \unorm{v}^2.
Both \inprod{\zerovec}{\uvec{v}} = 0 and \inprod{\uvec{v}}{\zerovec} = 0.

proof.p: We will prove only Rule and leave the rest up to you, the reader. (Though some of these are just restatements of the inner product axioms.)

Following the advice of , consider \inprod{\zerovec}{\uvec{v}} = \inprod{k \zerovec}{\uvec{v}} = k \inprod{\zerovec}{\uvec{v}} , which holds for every scalar k by Rule (or, really, by Axiom RIP). If we take scalar k = 0, then we get \inprod{\zerovec}{\uvec{v}} = 0 \inprod{\zerovec}{\uvec{v}} = 0 , as desired.
The symmetric formula \inprod{\uvec{v}}{\zerovec} = 0 then follows by Rule (or, really, by Axiom RIP).

subsection.p: Most of the rules above also hold for complex inner products, but there are some wrinkles due to the complex conjugate.

proposition.title: Algebra rules of complex inner products

statement.p:
Suppose \inprod{\blank}{\blank} is a complex inner product. Then the following are true for all vectors \uvec{u}, \uvec{v}, and \uvec{w} in the associated inner product space, and all scalars a.
\uvecinprod{v}{u} = \lcconj{\uvecinprod{u}{v}}.
\inprod{\uvec{u}}{\uvec{v} + \uvec{w}} = \uvecinprod{u}{v} + \uvecinprod{u}{w}.
\inprod{\uvec{u}}{\uvec{v} - \uvec{w}} = \uvecinprod{u}{v} - \uvecinprod{u}{w}.
\inprod{\uvec{u} + \uvec{v}}{\uvec{w}} = \uvecinprod{u}{w} + \uvecinprod{v}{w}.
\inprod{\uvec{u} - \uvec{v}}{\uvec{w}} = \uvecinprod{u}{w} - \uvecinprod{v}{w}.
\inprod{a \uvec{u}}{\uvec{v}} = a \uvecinprod{u}{v}.
\inprod{\uvec{u}}{a \uvec{v}} = \cconj{a} \uvecinprod{u}{v}.
\uvecinprod{v}{v} = \unorm{v}^2.
Both \inprod{\zerovec}{\uvec{v}} = 0 and \inprod{\uvec{v}}{\zerovec} = 0.

proof.p: We will prove only Rule and leave the rest up to you, the reader. (Though some of these are just restatements of the inner product axioms.)

subsection.p: The addition and scalar multiple rules for inner products can be combined to demonstrate that a real inner product is bilinear ( linear in both terms), while a complex inner product is sesquilinear ( linear in the first term but conjugate-linear in the second).

ol.li:
A real inner product is bilinear. That is, for all vectors \uvec{u}, \uvec{v}, \uvec{w} in a real inner product space, and all scalars a and b, we have
\inprod{a \uvec{u} + b \uvec{v}}{\uvec{w}} \amp = a \uvecinprod{u}{w} + b \uvecinprod{v}{w},
\inprod{\uvec{u}}{a \uvec{v} + b \uvec{w}} \amp = a \uvecinprod{u}{v} + b \uvecinprod{u}{w}.

A complex inner product is sesquilinear. That is, for all vectors \uvec{u}, \uvec{v}, \uvec{w} in a complex inner product space, and all scalars a and b, we have
\inprod{a \uvec{u} + b \uvec{v}}{\uvec{w}} \amp = a \uvecinprod{u}{w} + b \uvecinprod{v}{w},
\inprod{\uvec{u}}{a \uvec{v} + b \uvec{w}} \amp = \cconj{a} \uvecinprod{u}{v} + \cconj{b} \uvecinprod{u}{w}.

subsection.p: The properties of norm that we encountered using the dot product in \R^n remain true in every inner product space.

statement.p:
The following are true for all vectors \uvec{u} and \uvec{v} in an inner product space (real or complex) and all scalars k.
\unorm{v} \ge 0, and \unorm{v} = 0 only for \uvec{v} = 0.
\norm{-\uvec{v}} = \unorm{v}.
\norm{k\uvec{v}} = \abs{k}\unorm{v}, where \abs{k} indicates the ordinary absolute value of k in the context of a real inner product space, but indicates the complex modulus of k in the context of a complex inner product space.
\norm{\uvec{v}-\uvec{u}} = \norm{\uvec{u}-\uvec{v}}.

subsection.p: Both and the remain true in every inner product space, real or complex.

statement.p: For every pair of vectors \uvec{u} and \uvec{v} in an inner product space, we have \abs{\udotprod{u}{v}} \le \unorm{u}\unorm{v}, where \abs{\udotprod{u}{v}} indicates the ordinary absolute value in the real context and the complex modulus in the complex context.
For every pair of vectors \uvec{u} and \uvec{v} in an inner product space, we have \norm{\uvec{u}+\uvec{v}} \le \unorm{u} + \unorm{v}.

subsection.p: A vector can always be normalized to a unit vector.

statement.p:
For nonzero vector \uvec{v} in an inner product space, the unit vectors in \Span \{\uvec{v}\} are
\frac{k}{\unorm{v}} \uvec{v} \text{,} \qquad \text{for} \qquad \abs{k} = 1 .

proof.title: Proof idea
proof.p: Just calculate \norm{\frac{k}{\unorm{v}} \uvec{v}} using Rule of , and simplify to get 1.

remark.p: As usual, in the above proposition \abs{k} indicates the ordinary absolute value in the real context and the complex modulus in the complex context. The only two real scalars that satisfy \abs{k} = 1 are k = \pm 1. But in the complex context, there are an infinite number of scalars that satisfy this condition: the entire unit circle in the complex plane.

subsection.title: Inner products of \R^n and \C^n
subsection.p:
Finally we'll address what we learned about alternative inner products in
and .

proposition.title: Modified dot products are inner products

ol.li: If A is a positive definite real matrix, then the pairing \uvecinprod{u}{v} = \utrans{\uvec{v}} A \uvec{u} defines an inner product on \R^n.
If A is a positive definite complex matrix, then the pairing \uvecinprod{u}{v} = \adjoint{\uvec{v}} A \uvec{u} defines an inner product on \C^n.

proof.title: Proof outline
proof.p: In the real case, assuming A is positive definite means, by definition, that A is symmetric and that the pairing defined in the statement satisfies Axiom RIP. The symmetry of A addresses Axiom RIP, which leaves only Axiom RIP and Axiom RIP, which are easily confirmed using the properties of matrix algebra ().
The complex case is similar, with self-adjointness taking the place of symmetry.

subsection.p: The converse of the above proposition is true as well.

theorem.title: Inner products are modified dot products

ol.li: If \inprod{\blank}{\blank} is an inner product on \R^n, then there exists a positive definite real matrix A such that \uvecinprod{u}{v} = \utrans{\uvec{v}} A \uvec{u} for all \uvec{u},\uvec{v} in \R^n.

If \inprod{\blank}{\blank} is an inner product on \C^n, then there exists a positive definite complex matrix A such that \uvecinprod{w}{z} = \adjoint{\uvec{z}} A \uvec{w} for all \uvec{w},\uvec{z} in \C^n.

proof.p: We will prove only the real case; the complex case is similar.

First, notice that for every matrix A, \utrans{\uvec{e}}_i A \uvec{e}_j = a_{ij} , where a_{ij} is the (i,j) entry of A and \uvec{e}_i,\uvec{e}_j are standard basis vectors, as usual. So if we set A to be the matrix with entries a_{ij} = \inprod{\uvec{e}_j}{\uvec{e}_i} , then we have \inprod{\uvec{e}_i}{\uvec{e}_j} = a_{ji} = \utrans{\uvec{e}}_j A \uvec{e}_i , which is a start. And, as usually is the case, what is true for basis vectors will be true for all vectors.

aside.title: Notice
aside.p: Because of Axiom RIP, we actually have a_{ij} = \inprod{\uvec{e}_i}{\uvec{e}_j}, which is a more pleasing way to state the relationship between entries of A and inner product values of the standard basis vectors.

proof.p:
It only remains to verify that A is positive definite. Using Axiom RIP, we have
a_{ij} = \inprod{\uvec{e}_j}{\uvec{e}_i} = \inprod{\uvec{e}_i}{\uvec{e}_j} = a_{ji} , so A is symmetric. And the fact that \utrans{\uvec{v}} A \uvec{u} = \uvecinprod{u}{v} , that we have verified above, guarantees that \utrans{\uvec{v}} A \uvec{v} \gt 0 for all nonzero \uvec{v}, by Axiom RIP.

subsection.p: Finally, we verify the method of constructing positive definite matrices discussed in .

ol.li: If P is an invertible real matrix, then A = \utrans{P} P is a positive definite real matrix.
If P is an invertible complex matrix, then A = \adjoint{P} P is positive definite complex matrix.

proof.p: Again, we will provide the proof only in the real context; the complex context is similar.
